item.text: Have you limited system access to only approved people, devices, and tools? What is the current status?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – Only authorized employees, devices, and apps can log in.
Partially implemented – Some access is restricted, but gaps remain.
Not implemented – Anyone with the link or device can get in without checks.
Not applicable – No systems in scope hold sensitive contract data.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

Access Control Policy is a written, approved document that explains who is allowed to use company systems, what devices can connect, and what access they have.

item.text: Do you have an Access Control Policy?

valueCoding.display: Yes
No

item.text: Does your documented access control policy address these items?

valueCoding.display: Purpose, scope, roles, and responsibilities
Management commitment
Coordination among organizational entities
Compliance requirements

extension.valueString: Access Control Policy is a written, approved document that explains who is allowed to use company systems, what devices can connect, and what access they have.
Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

Access Control Policy Elements defines the official "rulebook" for managing a user's access rights throughout their time with the company. It covers the entire lifecycle of access, from start to finish.

•   Defining Permissions (Who & What): Sets clear rules for who is allowed to access what data. For example, a salesperson can see customer records, but not HR files.
•   Granting Access (How it's given): The formal process for giving a user new permissions, which typically requires approval from their manager.
•   Reviewing Access (How it's checked): The process for regularly checking user permissions to ensure they are still necessary for their current job role.
•   Revoking Access (How it's removed): The process for promptly and completely removing a user's permissions when they leave the company or change jobs.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

item.text: How many accounts are currently in your systems?

extension.valueString: Account means any login that can access your company’s systems — whether it belongs to an employee, a former employee, or even a software tool. Tracking the total number of accounts helps ensure only the right people and tools have access.
These are the logins for people currently working in your company who can access your systems. Each employee should have their own unique account.
Inactive Accounts are logins that no longer work — for example, when an employee leaves or changes roles. They should be turned off quickly so old accounts don’t become a back door.

Service Accounts are special logins used by software or automated tools, not people. For example, a program that runs nightly backups may need its own account. They still need to be tracked and secured.
Shared Accounts are logins with passwords that multiple people use. They are risky because you can’t tell who did what. Best practice is for everyone to have their own account instead of sharing.

Maintain a detailed and up-to-date record of all user accounts, including their access levels and status

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

item.text: This control makes sure only the right people, the allowed tools and services they use, and approved company devices should be able to get into your systems.
What is the status of least privilege implementation (making sure employees only have access to the specific actions their role requires, for example, read vs. edit vs. approve)?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – access is role-based and regularly reviewed.
Partially implemented – some roles limited, others still too broad.
Not implemented – all users have broad access.
Not applicable – no sensitive transactions in scope.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

item.text: How do you limit employees to only the system actions their job requires?

valueCoding.display: By job role (e.g., managers vs. staff have different access).
By type of action (e.g., can read data but not edit or delete it).
By application (e.g., only certain people can use a given tool).
By time (e.g., access only during work hours).
By location (e.g., access only from the office or approved networks).

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

It’s not enough to control who can log in — you also need to control what they can do once inside. Each person should only be able to carry out the tasks their role requires. For example, reading vs editing invoices, viewing vs deleting customer data.

item.text: What is the status of your controls over outside connections (internet, cloud tools, personal devices)?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – Only approved external systems can connect; all activity is monitored.
Partially implemented – Some external connections are controlled, but gaps remain.
Not implemented – Any system or device can connect without restriction.
Not applicable – No external systems connect to the environment in scope.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

item.text: What kinds of outside systems or devices connect to your company’s network or data? (Think about email, file sharing, partner portals, or employee devices.)

valueCoding.display: Cloud services – e.g., Microsoft 365, Google Workspace, Dropbox, Salesforce.
Business partner networks – e.g., joint project portals, shared databases.
Vendor/supplier systems – e.g., ERP integrations, supplier ordering platforms.
Government systems and portals – e.g., DoD contractor portals, SAM.gov, PIEE.
Personal devices (BYOD) – e.g., employees’ personal laptops, phones, or tablets.
Remote access systems – e.g., VPN, Citrix, Microsoft RDP.
No external connections – We keep all systems completely internal.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

Manage and secure connections to external systems to protect your network from unauthorized access and data breaches.

item.text: How do you check that outside systems and devices are safe before they connect to your network?

valueCoding.display: We use digital certificates and PKI to prove identity.
We require VPN logins with authentication before allowing access.
We set firewall rules or restrict by IP address so only approved connections get through.
We use signed agreements with partners/vendors that spell out security requirements.
We continuously monitor and log external connections to spot suspicious activity.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

External System Authentication requires confirming that an outside system or device is really what it claims to be and meets your security standards before allowing it to connect to your network. Examples include requiring a secure login, using VPN or certificates, or checking that the device is company-approved.

External connections are any links between your company’s systems and outside systems — like the public internet, cloud services, vendor platforms, or even employees’ personal laptops and phones. These need to be controlled so sensitive contract data isn’t exposed.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

item.text: What's the status of your process to make sure sensitive contract information (FCI) isn’t accidentally posted on your website, social media, or other public systems?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – We have a written approval process, only authorized staff can post, and we review/remove public content regularly.
Partially implemented – Some controls are in place (e.g., only certain staff can post), but no formal review or monitoring.
Not implemented – Anyone can post content publicly without checks, and there is no process for review.

extension.valueString: Federal Contract Information (FCI) is any information your company gets from the U.S. government under a contract that isn’t meant for the public. For example, it could be contract details, project schedules, or technical requirements. It does not include information the government makes public (like what you see on official websites).
